course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Introduction to Embedded Systems
course.description: This course is designed to teach techniques on how to integrate machine-level software and hardware in ARM-core microcontroller based systems. It makes use of industry-standard techniques and technologies, from which students can interface, design and program microcontroller systems. The task of the course will be to complete five laboratory experiments which address different aspects of hardware/software interfacing, and one large microprocessor/microcontroller based project which should result in the design and implementation of a small working embedded system.
course.prerequisites: COMP 2611 OR ELEC 2300 OR ELEC 2350 OR ISDN 4000F

reviews.author: 高海千歌
reviews.title: Sorry to say, but I just hate this course...
reviews.comment_content:
Embedded system. But most of the time they focus on concept and teach very little on how to operate the embedded system practically in the lecture. Then, you need to figure them by yourself during the lab. Tada

I feel like I learning nothing after this course. However, the thing which really terrified me is not the teaching or the content.

IT IS THE FUXKING PROJECT.

This is the ultimate problem maker of this course. It is a complete torture for me. And I really hope that it can fuxk off when I am dealing with the course throughout the semester.

When Fox is designing this course. He probably thought that:
a.) We are all come from robotics team who are very passionate, enthusiastic and sophisticated in embedded system.
b.) We are genius or prodigy who have infinite amount of creativity and organizational ability to make a stunning invention in short time to impress the teaching team with extremely high standards.
c.) We have infinite amount of time every day so that we can have enough time to deal with the complex project
d.) We only enroll ELEC3300 in the semester so that we can put all our time to deal with this course

Unfortunately, none of them are applicable for me. Tbh, me and my project member are "CS refugees" who cannot enter CS but end up CPEG. Both of us focus on COMP side and not really interested in hardware. Sadly, we are forced to enroll this course due to the requirement and suffered a lot.

We are newbie in embedded system. We know nothing beforehand, not even a single module. Moreover, we don't have abundant creativity to come up with a good project topic. As a result, we can only somehow replicate and integrate the things taught in labs with some modifications.

But guess what. Look at the harsh rubrics (Number in the bracket are the corresponding level)

Project Complexity :
Project  hardware  is  a  mix  of analogue  and digital  signals, software  part  used  majority lab‐covered features  of  the processor. (1/4)

Design Justification :
System  is  designed  only  according  to the  LAB  material. (2/4)

Project Originality :
Project  is  an  application  of  all  the labs done before. (2/4)

If you want to be at least decent (Only decent. Not even the best)?

Project Originality :
"Extended  integration"  of  lab materials with "extra circuits or software". (3/4)

Yep. We applied what we learnt. And we end up shitty grade with barely pass. Because we are not genius or robotics team who are able to come up with some extra "out-syllabus" element as "wow factor" to impress the teaching team. WOW. Is this an introductory course?

I clearly experience what the quote "Lose at the starting line" (輸在起跑綫) in Chinese means because it obviously depicts my ELEC3300 life.

We know Fox always have high standards and expectations on us. Moreover, I know Fox want to offer us some hands-on experience on embedded system. However, for this course the ability disparity is really large. Some CPEG students who are complete newbie or have no interest in embedded system are forced to face the harsh project standards and compete with those robotics team, which is painful. Being one of the important staffs in the CPEG program, Fox can you consider the feeling of us, CPEG students?

In the first lab (or the first tutorial?), he mentioned that "This is a hard course. If you don't want to suffer. Now it is still add-drop period..."

IF THIS IS NOT A CPEG REQUIRED COURSE, DO YOU FUXKING THINK THAT I WILL STAY AT HERE TO SUFFER???

Tbh, I would suggest CPEG students only need to choose between ELEC3300 and COMP3511 as requirement, but not both. Because some may want to focus more on one side (either ELEC or COMP), but not the other. It is better if there are some flexibility on 3000 level compulsory courses as well. (Just like COMP2611 vs ELEC2350 or COMP2711 vs ELEC2600)

I give a conclusion on this course:
a.) If you are CPEG students who are forced to suffer :
-> Good luck, god bless you. You can't escape. Try to find a robotics team guy as teammate to carry you. Otherwise, get ready to be obliterated by both the robotics team and the teaching team. They show no mercy to newbies.

b.) If you are non-CPEG students (ELEC major wanting to fulfill elective requirement or other random majors)
-> See if you fulfill any of the "Fox's ELEC3300 course design criteria" mentioned above (The a.) to d.) bullet points). If you do fulfill one of them, CONGRATULATIONS! you can enroll it and get a good grade.
-> If none of them are applicable to you, don't try it. Please run. Enrolling other courses are more meaningful to both your CGA and yourself. If you really want to learn embedded system, find other ways, but not taking this way which leads you to hell.
reviews.comment_teaching:
For prof. Tim Woo. He is a nice guy. However, his lecture is boring and I just didn't listen to him (Many students just did their own work during the lecture)

For main TA Fox, well, although I hate the course, I still praise Fox's teaching (but not grading standards). Fairly speaking, he explains things (concept, lab, project) well and I can still able to follow the content. But whether applying the lab material alone in the project is enough to impress him, that is another story.

For other TAs, I don't know, they are not really that helpful in the lab. Most of the time you ask them to debug, they just have no idea. Eventually, you have to debug by yourself.
reviews.comment_grading:
1. IPRS 8%
2. Assignments (x2) 10%
3. Lab (x6) 18%
4. Project 64%
a.) Preliminary proposal discussion (peer) 4%
b.) Proposal presentation 6%
c.) Interim project demonstration 9%
d.) Final demo & presentation 40%
e.) Final report 5%

Final demo result : 18.33/40
Mean : 21.10/40
SD : 8.92

For other domain I don't want to and I don't need to mention. Because at the time I know the final demo is below mean, I know my doom is coming.

What I can say is. As a student, don't expect too much from this course. In this course, only the teaching team can expect too much from students, but not the other way.

Update (31/12/2022)
Final grade : B-

Well...What is happening? Am I in heaven?

I can't imagine I score below mean in my project and I still manage to get a B-. Well I upgrade the rating at here for one level to appreciate that. However, the fact that this course is hard to score high still doesn't change. Be aware of that.
reviews.comment_workload:
1. IPRS
Forcing you to attend Tim Woo's boring lecture. However, the questions are easy. You may also find your neighbors to get the answer easily. It is not a big deal aside from wasting 80 mins in your life.

2. Assignment
Quite short and simple. Ask some concept stuff. Not a big problem.

3. Lab
Medium length. Some programming AND wire connection stuff. Better start working on it before the lab session. Otherwise, you are very likely not able to finish it. If you can finish the demo at the first 1 hour of the lab session, you can get 1 point bonus (and most people get it)

4. Project
Simply speaking, you need to make an invention by using embedded system in around two months of time, with a bunch of troublesome tasks.

However, 99.999999999999999% of workload comes from this piece of shxt. What makes it worse is that the return of this part is 99.999999999999999% not proportional to the input. What makes it the worst is that this piece of shxt determines 99.999999999999999% of your fate (i.e. grade). You may waste a lot of time in this course but end up shitty grade.

For my team, we stay in campus midnight for many days, trying to make our shitty product at least runnable with some input (Yeah, hardware debugging is way harder than software debugging). During those times, I just hate my life. And you can see my final result. Haha

Not to say our invention is relatively simple due to the lack of knowledge and it has already taken a lot of time. If you really want to impress the teaching team and make a much more complex product, you may need much more time to design, code and debug. Even two months are not enough at all while you need to deal with other courses as well.

Ah yes, this course may also cost you money because you need to buy most of the electronic gadgets for the project by yourself. Therefore, you need to waste both your time and your money and go to Sham Shui Po (or Taobao) to buy the gadgets. Please Fox, UST students don't have that time (and possibly money) to shopping. A blessing in disguise is that they provide reimbursement, but only $120 for each people.

Therefore, my advise is that if you are not really interested in but being forced to enroll this course, sacrifice it, save some time (and money) and focus on other courses to save your CGA

Once again, if you fulfill any of the "Fox's ELEC3300 course design criteria" mentioned in "CONTENT" part, you can simply skip my advise and enroll it to get good grade.

reviews.author: occheung
reviews.title: PSA: This course can be seriously difficult
reviews.comment_content:
An introductory course into embedded system. This course covers concepts and features like interrupts, timers, communication protocols, serial and parallel communications, as well as memory. Much emphasis is put onto coding in labs. A suitable amount of C programming skills is necessary to be able to handle the programming tasks. A minimal knowledge about assembly language is also needed.

Make sure you do the lab quickly, the 2 hours time limit seems liberal but in fact, it is very tight (most of the time). You may want to code beforehand and pray extra-extra-hard that your code just works flawlessly.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lectures are honestly boring. However, it does give you a good grasp of the fundamental concepts in data communications. If there is a real-time graded written assessment (i.e. midterm or final for some reason), understanding of these materials is pivotal for a decent course grade.

Tutorials are very informative. They kind of teach practical skillset for handling physical devices. Sometimes attending tutorials make your life easier when trying to figure out the solution for the lab exercise.

Labs are the practice part. Generally, you will be given a set of coding exercises/problems beforehand. You will need to demo your solution in lab time. Getting the correct solution requires much effort in some cases and it may take you a considerable amount of time. Here is the place where you will realize that life is much crueler than you thought, and your code can when you least suspect. Sometimes asking TAs and student helpers may make your life easier, sometimes not, especially if your coding approach is just completely wrong.

It is kind of the nature of programming-based assessments. Programming experience, knowledge of the language, coding styles etc. all comes into play. I had been a student helper for other courses as well, and I fully understand that sometimes other's code may just be weird. It can be something that I just cannot wrap my head around. It is reasonable that TAs just unable to pull you out of the hole that you, unfortunately, dug yourself into, and this is important to bear in mind.
reviews.comment_grading:
I split the grade composition into 2 parts.
Part 1:
In-class activities (iPRS): 7% + minor bonus
Homework: 4% x2
Lab task: 3% x7
Peer discussion for the final project proposal: 4%
Online presentation for the final project: 6%

Part 1 carries a total of 46%. Here is where things start to get interesting. Due to special circumstances (premature end of school term), an option is given to take final exam instead of continuing the final project. Therefore in part 2 of the composition:

Option 1:
Interim demo: 9%
Project demo + presentation: 40%
Report: 5%

Option 2:
Online final exam: 54%

(Sidenote: P/F or W were also available. Almost everyone are eligible to pass.)

I took the final exam, and I would urge you to not do the same.
Score: 153.5/180; Mean: 85.17; SD: 25.14

The mean is below 50%. The exam material covered al lot of the concepts taught within the course lecture (probably with the exception to direct memory access). It requires you to code from scratch. For example, instead of using HAL library for SPI communication (note: this is what people called bit-banging, now go look it up), we were required to implement helper functions to do the same thing ourselves with the aid of a timing diagram. One VERY LONG question also requires hardware connection, choice, and design, as well as programming a communication protocol for a piece of hardware. The difficulty of the exam is insane, even unthinkable for an ELEC course. I didn't see that coming at all.

Even if you don't take my words, the score tells you everything. So please think very very carefully before you take a written test designed by Fox. It could be the funeral for your CGA.

Needless to say, I got an A+ by the end (duh.)

Finally, WELL PLAYED FOX!
reviews.comment_workload:
Here is the rundown of what you will do in ELEC3300 sessions:
Lecture: Wait for iPRS and guess your way out.
Tutorial: Pretend to know everything even if you really don't
Before lab: Now you realize tutorial notes probably had told you everything you need to know, but you don't understand the notes
Lab: Beg your lab partner, TAs or some random nerds to do everything for you cuz you suck (jk)

In all seriousness, workload primarily concentrates on the labs and practical stuff. I would say the workload is not small. Here is some breakdown of workload.

+ Much effort is needed to fully understand lab materials and complete lab tasks.

+ If you do the project (which normally you must do so), the workload really depends on the complexity. Nevertheless, learning the methodology of datasheet skimming is non-trivial.

- Assignments are pretty easy tho. This also gave a lot of false comfort for us, thinking that the final exam is going to be just as painless and simple. (Spoiler alert! It wasn't.)

* No workload if you have the luxury /s of taking the final exam. Honestly, the lab material/tutorial slides are too simple. It really won't help you much to gear up for hardcore difficulty. But cranking up your experience may help a lot, so maybe you still want to buy some chips to play with. But then you will need to spend lots of time on things that don't count towards course grade...

So in terms of painfulness, the course project makes you feel the pain gradually. The final exam gives the same, but you feel all the pain during the exam. (maybe)

reviews.author: Mario Bus
reviews.title: Good arrangement amid Covid-19
reviews.comment_content:
(This is the start of the official description)
"This course is designed to teach techniques on how to integrate machine-level software and hardware in ARM-core microcontroller based systems. It makes use of industry-standard techniques and technologies, from which students can interface, design and program microcontroller systems. The task of the course will be to complete five laboratory experiments which address different aspects of hardware/software interfacing, and one large microprocessor/microcontroller based project which should result in the design and implementation of a small working embedded system."
This has been the official description of this course. In terms of courses provided by ECE, it really is a strange course:
1. It is the only 3000-level ELEC course that accepts a higher level COMP course (COMP2611) as a prerequisite.
2. It is a major required course only in BEng(CPEG), but not in BEng(ELEC) in which ELEC3300 is an optional course.
3. The TA of this course (Fox) is one of the important figures of CPEG Program Office. (Hope I didn't misuse the word "figure" :) )
Therefore I gave it a nickname course code: CPEG3010 :)
BTW, I love its content and it really gives me a glimpse on the industry.

(Tips: drones project good, even if it is overly used like a john)
P.S.: Should you find this review useful and you are planning to take this course in 2022 Spring, don't mind leaving a contact)

Nevertheless, maintaining "a small working embedded system" (exact wordings from the official course description) is not difficult if you know how to use the computer software for code writing, debugging, etc.

reviews.author: DrainGang
reviews.title: Heavy workload, however you are doing something useful.
reviews.comment_content:
1.Introduction to Embedded Systems
2.Basic Computer Structure
3.Microcontroller Structure
4.Interrupt Organization
5.Timer and Counter
6.Interfacing LCD
7.Motor Interfacing
8.Introduction to use of Equipment
9.Number System and STM32 Structure
10.I/O and Interrupt function of STM32
11.Controlling Graphic LCD using FSMC function of STM32
12.STM32 Timer and PWM Function
13.ADC of STM32
14.I2C function of STM32

Basic introduction to microcontrollers, just teaching you how to use the various functions and protocols on the STM32 and how to read datasheets. You only have lectures for the first half of the semester. With the assessment, this course is VERY much a hands-on course, so it is quite meaningful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Great teaching, professor Woo and professor Vinod both go over the concepts clearly. Classes are pretty interactive with the IPRS questions. They are also both very responsive to questions in class, feel free to ask for clarification.

As with most ELEC courses, the TAs are amazing. Fox goes over what you need to do in the labs and the related concepts very clearly, he also sends us emails quite often, reminding us of deadlines and such.
reviews.comment_grading:
Quite a lot of things, but NO EXAMS! The main thing is the project, with 2-people groups. A good tip for the project: make sure it has a lot of hardware components, the graders do not care much for software.

In-class activities (8%): IPRS questions in class, 6% is given if you answer all questions, and another 2% is given if you get more than 70% of questions right. The questions are not hard, however you need to pay attention in class, otherwise you won't be able to answer them. I got all 8% I believe.

2 assignments (10%, 5% each): Pretty simple questions, just making sure you understand the lecture materials. Almost everyone has full marks on this.

6 Lab experiments (18%, 3% each): Follow the lab manual and demo the circuit and code to the TAs, quite useful as you will do similar things for the final project, difficulty is low other than the last lab. Most people have at least 15/18% since the first 5 labs are quite easy.

Preliminary proposal discussion (4%): Meet with other students in a Zoom meeting and discuss the projects you will be making, and then write a short comment on iPeer. Just submitting it will give you all 4%.

Proposal presentation (6%): Make a video presenting the project idea. Points are given based on the complexity of the project. My presentation was quite bad so I got 3% or so possibly.

Interim project demo (9%): Show the TAs and professors your current progress in the demo, you are also allowed to ask them questions on the project for feedback. Grading is completely unknown, but I think we did alright.

Final project demo and presentation (40%): Make a 7 minute video demonstrating your project and then also explain the flow of the code. After the video the TAs and professors will ask you questions on the project. (Average score: 19.7, SD: 5.01)

Final report (5%): Make a HTML file storing everything in the project, just linking everything you have already done on it. Again grading is unknown.

Nothing is shown other than my grade for the 2 assignments and the final score, with 3.5/40 higher than the average I got a B. Decent? Really unsure.
reviews.comment_workload:
VERY heavy.

No matter what you are doing for the project, you will spent a LOT of time debugging and trying to solve technical issues, some of which will have NO ANSWERS online, meaning that you really have to solve them yourself. (For example, I searched for a VERY long time for a library and could not find it, I only managed to solve it by bruteforcing what I wanted instead of an elegant solution.)

Depending on the ability of your groupmate, the workload also varies, but again, it is heavy no matter what.

reviews.author: kalung
reviews.title: Effort pays for itself
reviews.comment_content:
This course teach the basics of embedded system
STM32F1 and cubemx is used for both teaching and (most likely) your project
Keil MDK µVision 5 is the IDE of teaching
*but I use makefile toolchain instead
*cubemx is useful when initializing your project
*beware of the difference of ARMCC and GCC if you want to use makefile /w vscode
==================
Course content
==================
some basic of elec2350(e.g. little endian vs big endian)
polling vs interrupt(remember the ISR priority)
how to read timing diagram
how to read datasheet(*IMPORTANT)
how to setup cubemx for project generation
basic component of MCU(ADC PWM GPIO)
FSMC and LCD and I2C
some protocol(UART SDIO I2C)
==================
LAB content
==================
LAB1 - tinkercad
LAB2 - GPIO
LAB3 - FSMC LCD(rgb565)
LAB4 - Timer and PWM
LAB5 - ADC
LAB6 - I2C

reviews.author: TrebledJ
reviews.title: Unpopular opinon: nice and fun hands-on project experience
reviews.comment_content:
Got some dream IoT gadget or a fun toy idea? This might be the place to start building it.

There'll 6 labs to complete, 1 interim (midterm) demo, 1 final demo. Attendance is marked by IPRS.

The labs can be done at home. You just come to lab to demo or ask questions.

For the project, you're limited to the STM family of boards. They provide a development kit complete with an STM32F103 board, ST-Link, touchscreen LCD, simple sensors, a servo, pins for I2C/SPI, pins for a WiFi module, pins for a camera, and whatnot. (See attachment.)

Content:
• Introduction and Overview of Embedded Systems
• Review of Low-Level Computing (COMP2611 review)
• LCD, FSMC
    - Useful for displays/interaction
• Interrupts
    - Useful if your device doesn't need to run all the time or if you have something special to trigger
• Timers, PWM
    - Useful for regular signals, interrupts
• ADC/DAC (Analog-to-Digital Conversion and vice versa), Motors
    - Useful for analog sensors, motors, audio
• Serial Communication (UART, USB, SPI, Zigbee)
    - Useful for communicating w/ sensors/devices/computers
• DMA
    - Useful for performance

Other things you might be able to pick up:
 • Reading signal diagrams
• Hunting info in datasheets
• Googling
• Screaming in pain at 2am

All in all, it's pretty ambitious for an intro to embedded systems.

----

Some experience sharing.

Like with most courses, you'll get more out if you enter with some  fundamentals. I entered with some robotics experience (so I guess my review doesn't speak for everyone). Of course I don't know everything, there were still a lot of new things that I picked up from this course.

Our group started planning for the course before the semester started. I wanted to make something music related, so we decided on making a MIDI keyboard of sorts.

We decided to forgo the F1 board and chose an F4 board. (Unless you have an EE groupmate, I suggest not taking this approach, as you'll likely be soldering things, designing the PCB, etc.) But we went for an F4 for speed and memory.

We also used C++. Slightly more flexible on the generics/container side of things. It might be possible to do it in Rust. Maybe a bit risky though, portability of libraries and all that.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Bittersweet?

Tim Woo and Fox are both passionate instructors. Tim Woo uses good analogies. He does show some videos in the first few weeks, but these are mostly inspirational rather than contentful. The IPRS is not too bad. It tries to get you to think and dig into the details.

Some topics were rushed though. And the slides are rather messy, so it's a bit hard to find info.

You can tell Fox is rather passionate about teaching, and he guides the TAs well. The rubrics seem thorough, detailed, and fair, but it might be a bit overthought. In the end, it's up to human TAs who might have very different opinions. Nonetheless, they do put a lot of effort into explaining the rubric, giving past examples, etc.

Tutorials are skippable, but are useful for setting up things and gaining a detailed understanding. E.g. why might the ADC rate be slower when we set a higher clock rate?

TAs shared their projects and experience in the last few weeks. I completely skipped these lectures (bc 9am), but I guess they could be eye-opening if you're invested into the field.
reviews.comment_grading:
Most of your grades will come from the project. Project criteria are: complexity, design, originality, completeness, presentation. (See attachment.)

I think grading for the (final) project was okay? At least for us. Again, a lot depends on the TAs. Some have high expectations. Some have none.

The interim demo grades were very weird. Most groups I know (including mine) got around half the marks. What do the TAs expect? A fully functional product? ...four weeks into the project? ...during midterms???

I skipped a bunch of IPRS towards the end. (Who wants to get up at 9am just to be interrupted (haha!) by IPRS?)

In the end, I managed to pull an A range, which was okay considering the effort I put into the project minus the missed IPRS and the unreasonable interim grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not gonna lie, ELEC3300 bears comparatively high workload to other courses, but this is natural when it comes to being a hands-on/project-based course. Add to this the nature of hardware and software (bugs!). And the chance of grouping with a freerider.

Bugs are the most painful part of the project. There are software bugs. And then there are hardware bugs. If a bug persists for a while, what I would do is: (1) ask experts (e.g. Fox, online forums such as stackexchange), (2) ask other groups (esp. those who have similar projects).

To give an example, I had an issue with speakers. Emailed Fox; vague response. Asked in DSP.SE; got some answer about psychoacoustics. 🤷‍♂️ Eventually I was able to resolve an issue with speakers in my project by asking another group what they used for speakers and how they handled them. Apparently the hardware design was simpler than we thought.

As mentioned above, some lecture materials were rushed through. Truth be told, you can get away with not knowing, especially if the topic is not used in lab or in your project. Otherwise, you'll need to self-study to catch up.

This semester they allowed us to form groups of 3. (Previously it was only groups of 2.) I found my groupmate early on and we already had most things planned by early September (a week into Fall?). Fortunately, my groupmate shared a decent chunk of responsibility, so we ended up with a finished product.

I guess my takeaways here are: don't underestimate the workload, find good groupmate(s), communicate well, and don't be afraid to seek help.

Also: set achievable targets.

I will not say the exam is hard, it is open everything and all materials are provided, but I will say it is very intense.
Q1 circuit simulation using TinkerCad (43min)
Q2 given datasheet of IC, write some driver functions (43min)
Q3 given datasheet of IC and an STM32 chip version, draw wiring + generate CubeMX project + code in C using HAL_library (73min)

If you know how to extract useful information from datasheets and understand the timing diagram quickly, and then write the working code quickly, and most importantly understand what the question is asking quickly, you will be able to submit a solution a few minutes before the deadline. If you don't, practice datasheets reading, just to know how to code that chip to work by reading the minimum amount of content, which is also the assignments are doing.
